channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Time for US-Plus-One?
item.description: When China became a riskier economic proposition, its partners diversified. America’s allies should do the same.

item.title: China Responds to Trump’s Revived Monroe Doctrine
item.description: Amid the U.S. naval blockade announcement off the coast of Venezuela, Beijing has released its new strategy for the region.

item.title: Japan-Korea relations: Sanae's puzzling provocation
item.description: The new prime minister's claim over disputed islands was made with a domestic audience in mind.

item.title: Trump Hasn’t Learned From History in Latin America
item.description: The former leaders of Colombia and Mexico are concerned over recent U.S. actions

item.title: Benin’s Failed Coup Reveals Deepening Fault Lines in Africa
item.description: The foiled putsch placed the continent’s geopolitics under a magnifying glass.

item.title: U.S. Announces Largest-Ever Arms Deal With Taiwan
item.description: Washington aims to help Taipei outmatch Chinese military capabilities by focusing on asymmetric warfare.

item.title: U.S. Announces $11.1 Billion Arms Package for Taiwan
item.description: Washington aims to help Taipei outmatch Chinese military capabilities by focusing on asymmetric warfare.

item.title: Trump’s AI Mineral Hunt Goes Global
item.description: The White House’s tech ambitions have intensified its critical minerals scramble.

item.title: Judge Bans Trump From Laying off Hundreds of Diplomats Through January
item.description: The six-week injunction covers roughly 250 foreign service officers.

item.title: How Chinese cars are beating European tariffs
item.description: Carmakers are adapting to Europe’s EV barriers

item.title: America’s Civilizational Suicide
item.description: By heaping abuse on Europe and handling Russia and China with kid gloves, the Trump administration's National Security Strategy represents a radical departure from past US policies. But even as America rejects everything it once stood for, Europeans' only choice is to double down on their own principles.

item.title: Seen from above, el-Fasher is a ghost town
item.description: Satellite imagery reveals how North Darfur’s capital has been abandoned after its fall

item.title: Brazil’s Bold Industrial Turn
item.description: Despite strong opposition in Congress, Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has launched an ambitious industrial policy aimed at boosting renewable-energy capacity and expanding domestic defense capabilities. But sky-high interest rates and fiscal constraints risk putting these objectives out of reach.

item.title: U.S. Strategists Keep Getting France’s Defeat Wrong
item.description: Myths about the Maginot Line are strangely persistent.

item.title: The Transatlantic Rupture Is Complete
item.description: Under President Donald Trump, the United States is seeking to create a world order based solely on spheres of interest controlled by the US, China, and Russia. And because this will require breaking up the European Union, the decades-long transatlantic alliance has given way to enmity in remarkably short order.

item.title: The element of surprise: Bondi and the Australian "conceptzia"
item.description: Surprise remains a central feature of Australia's security environment.

item.title: Don’t Let Trump Destroy the G-20
item.description: Barring South Africa will fundamentally weaken the G20. Its members must push back.

item.title: Decision Time for Europe
item.description: Given the Trump administration’s recent statements and policy pronouncements, European leaders no longer have any excuse for failing to map out their own long-term security strategy. If they can get their act together on ending the Ukraine war, they will gain a much stronger position on other key fronts, too.

item.title: Iran’s First SCO Military Exercise Solidifies Ties With China and Russia
item.description: “Sahand 2025” marks a major milestone in Tehran’s integration into the Shanghai Cooperation Organization – and in its pursuit of greater international recognition.

item.title: The 3 AI Problem: How Chinese, European, and American Chatbots Reflect Diverging Worldviews
item.description: A test of the ideological biases of three leading AI models from China, Europe, and the U.S. returned some surprising results.

item.title: Your Well Informed guide to surviving Christmas
item.description: Drink slowly, eat cake and remember that fun is good for you, too

item.title: The Economist’s country of the year for 2025
item.description: Which country improved the most this year?

item.title: What Novo Nordisk, OpenAI and Pop Mart have in common
item.description: All three have suffered the curse of overnight success

item.title: Two months in, the Gaza ceasefire is floundering
item.description: The consequences will ripple beyond the Middle East

item.title: China proved its strengths in 2025—and Donald Trump helped
item.description: It was a good year for Xi Jinping

item.title: A vote against gerrymandering shows why political courage is rare
item.description: Yet it is particularly valuable now

item.title: More schools in America are adopting a four-day week
item.description: Teachers and parents like it, but results for pupils are middling

item.title: Toll roads are spreading in America
item.description: The decline of petrol taxes is to blame

item.title: The weekly cartoon
The world this year 2025
How to conduct a job interview
item.description: The worst way to select people, except for all the others

item.title: Luxury handbags may be shoddier than you think
item.description: Complaints about quality are a growing worry for brands from Chanel to Prada

item.title: Just 74 intensive-care beds remain in Gaza
item.description: The health-care system is shattered and no one is rebuilding it

item.title: The botched response to a devastating storm infuriates Indonesians
item.description: Nationalism impeded the arrival of help from abroad

item.title: Can Australia defend itself against jihadist murderers?
item.description: The father and son who killed 15 in Sydney may have sought training in the Philippines

item.title: The Christmas-industrial complex centres on Yiwu
item.description: How Chinese traders beat out Lapland’s elves

item.title: Ditch textbooks and learn how to use a wrench to AI-proof your job?
item.description: Generation Z is becoming less invested in university and more interested in skilled trades

item.title: European nationalism is dead. Long live European gastronationalism
item.description: A continent united by treaties remains divided by recipes

item.title: Italy is using the Winter Olympics to appeal to the ultra-wealthy
item.description: In Milan, everyone is going for gold

item.title: Why German cities feel like war zones on New Year’s Eve
item.description: A dream for pyromaniacs, a nightmare for everyone else

item.title: Jimmy Lai’s Criminal Conviction Epitomizes China’s Cognitive Warfare
item.description: The ruling is a capstone in the ongoing effort to rewrite the history of Hong Kong and its pro-democracy movement – using the once-respected courts.

item.title: What’s Behind the ISIS Attack in Syria
item.description: Ahmed al-Sharaa is serious about battling extremists, but his country isn’t fully under government control.

item.title: Kazakh Senate Approves Law Banning ‘LGBTQ’ Propaganda”
item.description: The law goes to President Tokayev next for signature.

item.title: Watch who you’re calling childless
item.description: Women in America are having as many babies over their lifetimes as they did two decades ago

item.title: Meet the American investors rushing into Congo
item.description: They are taking on war, corruption and China

item.title: How the young can make sense of the news
item.description: With your help, the Economist Educational Foundation can teach children to think critically

item.title: The World Needs a Space COP
item.description: Negotiating a new treaty to manage congestion and competition in space seems hopeless, but a workable mechanism exists.

item.title: Underground and in the Shadows: How Uzbekistan Lives With Its Radioactive Legacy
item.description: The lack of transparent monitoring data and public access to environmental information significantly increases risks for communities living near former uranium facilities.

item.title: Thailand, Cambodia Agree to Deployment of ASEAN Observers, Malaysian PM Says
item.description: Despite an apparent lull yesterday evening, fighting continues to rage at various points along the two nations' 817-kilometer border.

item.title: The Middle East’s Most Overlooked Threat
item.description: How the Houthis—and a new civil war in Yemen—could upend the post-Gaza balance of power.

item.title: India Doesn’t Know How Many Foreigners With Expired Visas Are in the Country
item.description: The ministry has often resorted to knee-jerk reactions while tackling illegal immigration, best evidenced by its policies in Assam.

item.title: What a student of security studies thinks of Australia’s national strategy
item.description: The country’s security should be a shared democratic project but the conversations too often sideline the young.
